User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:6.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/6.0
Build ID: 20110811165603

Steps to reproduce:

I got to comment on the this, as this is a pet peeve of mine:

The 

    "When I open a link in a new tab, switch to it immediately" CHECK BOX

under Tools > Options > Tabs.

WHY isn't this always checked as the DEFAULT? Instead of making users check it to get that behavior?

If I purposely, middle click with my mouse, why should FF not switch to that new tab I created immediately? 



Actual results:

No switching immediately


Expected results:

HERE IS MY REASONING:
Even if I right click and select, Open in New Tab, I really want to read that about the article just like I do with like a footnote. I don't just open a tab and decide to read it later. I like to read it "now" as I want INFORMATION, NOW, so I can better understand the rest of the article I am currently reading. Is that not the original beauty of the Internet and hyperlinks?

But say if some people want to open it up and read it AFTER the article, will that really help that person with the current article that you were reading as now you just tried to read an article where part of it you didn't understand fully in the first place.

So basically you kinda wasted you time on the first reading since you didn't bother to read that Newly Opened Tab that was trying to explain to you something that was needed for the rest of the article you were reading.

So, what I am saying is that Checkbox to switch to a new tab should be default checked just from a understand-first-in-what-you-are-reading stand point.

REASONING from a SECURITY STAND POINT
Plus, from a security standpoint as well. If I am going to open up a page, I really should see what that newly open tab is doing FIRST as you all know, all those popup and advertising is where viruses, and problems occur.

If you allow users to open up new tabs in the background, who knows what's going on. But if I bookmarked it and clicked on an entire folder, I should at least know and already visited what I bookedmarked in the first place, long ago.

I wouldn't not be surprised that this default checkbox state for opening new tabs could cause a lot of security issues from how the general public surfs the web with FF.

One of the first things I do when I install FF is goto Tools > Options and Tab and check that checkbox.

Allowing general users to open tab without forcing them to switch to it immediately could allow bad sites or advertisements from sites to their bad things without the user knowing about it.

Furthermore, having popup, popping up, could cause users to hit the wrong button and install that bad stuff. Or say if that new page is a huge video or just a big page, users could perceive that the Firefox is slowing down on their current page when in reality it was that newly created tab *opened in the background* downloading some large flash video and that the user didn't know about it. We as developers will know it. But will the general non-tech user know it? In my experience, NO WAY will the non-tech user know about it. They will blame the browser or something else when it should have been that website in the tab opened in the background.

Well, just wanted to say that and filed it under General as I feel this covers several areas and not just tabs or preferences

comments.raw_text:
I think your usage is atypical. The most common reason users want to open in multiple tabs is because they want to follow more than one hyperlink on a page. For example, doing a Google search and then middle-clicking on the links that look relevant and then going through them.

> I like to read it "now" as I want INFORMATION, NOW

Then why not just regular-click on it, then use the back button when you want to go back? There's no real performance hit to the back button in FF; the page is not reloaded or anything.

As for security, if a page can do something harmful, it's going to do it as soon as it can. By the time the user has loaded the page, the damage has already been done, whether they are looking at it or not.

comments.raw_text:
While I don't know if my usage style of browsing is atypical, I do know that Mozilla did put a optional check mark on switching to newly open tabs immediately. That would mean someone else, other than me, would like switching to newly opened tab as well.

As for performance, switching between tabs is MUCH FASTER as there is no reloading of the page with the back button. I don't know about you, but when I click on a link on say a news article on yahoo, and then switch back I can already see some reloading. If I switch tabs, there definitely is no reloading, at least for me there isn't. And unless like there is another extension like BarTab that unloads the page after a certain time frame, switching tab is much faster for me. Yes, like a half second or more, but for me, I do notice it. And I think other users who do a lot of browsing might also.

As for security, I am referring to bad popups and maybe even multiple popups on a single page.  Furthermore, I would say there is sometimes a critical decision to close a bad popup. And if there are lots of popups on other pages opened in the background, the user could start to be impatient and just click away without more carefully viewing what is happening. By forcing the user to look at what is going on, at-a-one-page-at-a-time-basis, the user might not be inundated with popups that need to be closed or annoying where just a single popup could be mistaken for a bad one. 

I also think the Internet would do better if Microsoft's IE would also make their default checkbox to switch to that tab immediately as well.

Well, that's my opinion.
